issue.title: Cannot set custom data to `_ServiceContext` in aio grpc server interceptor

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
Hi! Recently I've switched to aio version of grpc and started rewriting our code. I came across a problem with server interceptors: it's impossible to add any kind of information to passed context! We use context for opentracing context e.g. After income metadata is processed we set `span` attribute to context in interceptor handler:
`context.span = span`
But it doesn't work anymore. Even `setattr` doesn't work. I think this is a bug.

Or is there any other way to set a custom data to `_ServicerContext` instance?

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/aio/server.pyx.pxi#L113

body:
> Before we fix it, as a workaround, we recommend pass data using serialized [metadata](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/python/grpcio/grpc/__init__.py#L1315).

Unfortunately, in my case these objects canâ€™t be serialized (like managed db session). Soâ€¦ please hurry ðŸ˜‡

The ability for gRPC to schedule callbacks on any thread in the threadpool is very much by design--applications should not rely on which thread gRPC decides to schedule callbacks on. That should be an implementation detail and subject to change. It sets a dangerous precedent if users start relying on such guarantees. The interceptor can wrap the incoming context and pass its own implementation to share information. If that is not super convenient, there needs to be an explicit facility to make that particular task easier.  Encouraging users to shove objects in thread locals is unwise.

@mehrdada as the linked issue details, the original question was about sharing data between multiple interceptors and the request handler as they process an incoming request â€” i.e. whatâ€™s the best way to pass data down that call chain and back up? The discussion isnâ€™t about sharing data across multiple call chains handling _different_ requests.

@jenstroeger I understand your concern. If I recall the discussion from many years ago, for the sync case, the idea was for the interceptor to create and pass a custom `ServicerContext`-derived object that wraps the incoming context and delegates its methods (probably easiest way to implement through some decorator like pattern) and carry satellite data in its extra custom-defined methods for the request handler to use (if modifying the request object did not make sense). I agree that this may be cumbersome and perhaps the solution may be for the library to provide a first party decorator facility to make it easier to accomplish, or perhaps directly a satellite data dictionary to the context object. However, in my opinion, this problem that does not justify making the library guarantee to the user which thread it is running which interceptor/handler on; that's a low-level implementation detail and will be brittle and scary (imagine a grpc update changes its underlying behavior intentionally or accidentally, and a user program suddenly runs a request handler with a different thread local associated with a separate request potentially exposing PII).
@mehrdada thatâ€™s interesting â€” but how does your recommendation play together with static types? See also comment https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/24470#issuecomment-1223867769.

Thanks for the suggestion @mehrdada! We agree that it's not a good idea to guarantee that interceptors and handles will be run in the same thread.

We plan to use an alternative solution for this issue:
Similar to the suggested use of `ServicerContext`, the gRPC library will create a new `contextVar` to store custom context and maintain it by propagating it across different threads. This way, the user will have a way to pass information around, and it also hides the thread implementation.

rename.from: [Python Sync] Interceptors and server handlers should run in the same thread
rename.to: [Python Sync] Implement a mechanism to propagate information between interceptors and server handlers.

body:
I'm a bit puzzled by some of the responses. I don't think anyone is requesting that interceptors and handlers be run in the same thread, and contextvars doesn't require it (one could temporarily associate a `Context` with a thread via `contextvars Context.run()`).

I think something [like this](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/compare/master...kcooney:grpc:context-vars) might work (I can't confirm since I can't seem to run tests grpc on my MacOS laptop).

_Edit:_ Got it working in a Linux VM. Sent out a PR.

issue.title: [Python] Use same contextvars.Context for interceptors and RPC handler

labels.name: release notes: no
